ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A LOT of emphasis is placed on handwriting characters. You'll probably develop a good system for learning/memorizing new vocabulary if you don't have one already.
In CHNS 152, the lessons are much more advanced. Many of the characters, grammar, and sentence structure were all new to me, but the words and  we learned are useful in conversation and writing.
Increased proficiency with the Chinese language, better language study habits moving forward
This course really helped me improve my reading/writing/comprehension skills in Chinese.
I learned Chinese vocabulary, grammar, and gained knowledge of how to converse in Chinese about topics such as politics and food.

I learned a lot of vocabulary (ranging from day-to-day phrases to more professional phrases) as well as sentence structures that I will continue to use when speaking more generally. The class structure also helped me improve my speaking skills since it was a complete immersion into Chinese.
This class has more focus on formal Chinese than previous classes, the structure is pretty similar and a reasonable step from L4.
I learned Chinese! My writing gains will inevitably be forgotten but I think my reading and conversational comfort have been greatly improved. Better than if I hadn't taken Chinese, anyways.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The course is very engaging and I always found it easy to find the motivation to work for it.

The course could be more uniform in that the chapters are a little disjointed and thus the vocabulary and grammar learned seem to be disconnected.

I thought that with all the reading and essays we did, our abilities to read and write improved drastically. I like how the classes aren't 5 days a week like L1/L3 courses. I felt like it was enough where I was routinely practicing my Chinese, but not overwhelmed.

Strengths: Very easy-to-follow textbook, with lots of examples and exercises. Professor was very encouraging and knowledgeable. 

Weaknesses: Could have benefitted from a wider variety of topics

The structure of each class was really consistent, so I knew what to expect when I came to class. I enjoyed how interactive it was and how our professor made sure we were engaging and working with the vocabulary.
Have more opportunities for just conversational speaking

The work was tedious but fine. I think it would have been nice to set up in-person conversation groups within the class. I don't think I learned like, most people's English names. Also, a lot of things were not mandatory which made them easy to skip.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, Chinese courses and professors have consistently been excellent. If you are passionate about Chinese culture and keen on learning reading, writing, and understanding the language, it's worth taking this class.
Absolutely! If you want to get better at Chinese this will definitely help, however you must be willing to put the work in.
Yes, especially if you are looking to improve your Chinese. If you don't enjoy learning the language, you will probably have a harder time, however, I personally really loved the course.
Yes, if you want to improve your grammar and vocabulary, as well as your written Chinese skills.

Yes! As a heritage speaker, it was nice to learn grammar and structure more formally instead of just relying on intutition. I also learned some of the more nuanced differences between phrases. that I thought meant the same thing.
Yes, it's a good class and I think my mandarin improved, just be ready for a pretty decent workload.
Yes, if you want to learn Chinese.
